results.title: The Last days work
results.brief_description: It is not just the threatening capacity of global nuclear war nor the disfiguration of natural ecological forces but rather it is the work people do that indicates the end of their use on this planet. If not destructive and wasteful in its own right modern work relies on others being so. This is a critical film essay about the final phase of work. It is built in seven parts which correspond to each day of the week.

results.title: The Last days of living
results.creator_credit: Malca Gillson, Tom Daly and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Looks at the Palliative Care Unit for the terminally ill at Montreal’s Royal Victoria Hospital, and the hardships and joys experienced by patients, their families and the staff. The palliative care techniques observed by the camera are simple and straight forward, such as listening, sharing, touching and music therapy. An essential film for health-care professionals and volunteers, and for the public at large.

results.title: The Last Crop
results.creator_credit: Sue Clayton, Billy MacKinnon, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Film Commission, Channel Four, Film Australia and Zenith
results.brief_description: Ann cleans for a living. She shares everything she has with her two moody children and her equally erratic neighbours but she also shares everything her rich and constantly out-of-town employers have. When Ann’s not sorting out the lives of her family and friends, she’s thinking about her father’s property in the country and how nice it would be to live there. Only one little international mining company stands in her way. But Ann, used to beating the system in her own quiet way, is not about to let that spoil her plans. The dry, quirky style of this wonderfully honest film portrays Australian life in a refreshingly unfashionable way. Based on the short story by Elizabeth Jolley.

results.title: The Language of maps
results.brief_description: Uses aerial photography, topographic models and maps to show that the language of maps is composed of symbols representing natural and man-made features of the earth’s surface.

results.title: The Land: Cumbrian Lake District
results.creator_credit: Richard Guinea, Julia Spark and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This film shows the distinctive landform features which have been produced by Ice Age glaciation in the Lake District in England. Explanations are given of the processes which have produced such geographical features; the impact of humans through tourism is also looked at. Presented by Bill Grundy.

results.title: The Land: a new priority
results.creator_credit: Roger Hart, Roman Bittman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This documentary concerns the struggle of rural people in the Third World. The film takes us into the rural communities of Senegal, Kenya, Mauritius, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, where foreign and local aid programs, combined with imaginative community projects, initiate small but significant changes. The brilliance of local dress, the traditional songs and dances, and the beautiful green images fail to mask the very real difficulty of finding a day’s food.

results.title: The Land that waited
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Alan Morris and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Using lithographs, engravings and water-colours, this film tells the story of the settlement of Australia, beginning with the arrival of Captain Phillip, and continuing with the toils and hardships of the early explorers and settlers on the alien, hostile continent. Winner of an Australian Film Award, gold award, for “its use of contemporary material in interpreting history”. Narrated by Nigel Lovell.

results.title: The Land of Senegal
results.creator_credit: Guy Sarthoulet, Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Dakar, the capital city of the West African country of Senegal, is a magnet for thousands of farmers who flock into town and then cannot find work. The country has a one-crop economy - but peanuts are particularly vulnerable to market price fluctuations, so the Government of Senegal has asked for United Nations help in diversifying agriculture and training a new class of craftsmen and skilled cultivators.

results.title: The Land of Robert Burns
results.creator_credit: Joe Mendoza, Stewart McAllister and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: This short account of the poet’s life is set among contemporary scenes of the people of south-west Scotland as they grow from childhood to adulthood. A representative selection of his songs, sung by the Saltire singers, takes on fresh significance when heard against a background of the people and the countryside he knew and loved.
